text: the August sarin gas attack near
Damascus killed an estimated 1,400 men
women and children
it drew global attention back to the
century-long struggle to stop the
scourge of chemical weapons
[Music]
in World War one both Germany and the
Allied nations widely used poison gas
chlorine phosgene and mustard gas
resulted in hundreds of thousands of
casualties out of that devastation came
the Geneva Protocol which forbade the
use of chemical and biological weapons
in armed conflict but that didn't stop
fascist Italy from using mustard gas
against the Ethiopians nor did it stop
the Japanese Imperial Army which used
the gas against the Chinese in the 1930s
during World War two Western countries
did not use chemical weapons in battle
but continued to build their stockpiles
and supply troops with gas mas in the
event of an attack Hitler who himself
was gassed during World War one refused
to order its use against combatants but
he allowed the Nazis to use zyklon-b
a cyanide based pesticide to execute
Jews Roma and prisoners of war
in the 1960s President Gamal Abdel
Nasser of Egypt ordered the use of
chemical weapons in Yemen during the
Cold War both the US and the Soviet
Union amassed massive stockpiles of
chemical weapons which they're still
destroying in the 1980's Saddam
Hussein's forces used chemical weapons
on a large scale during the iran-iraq
war they were used again around Halabja
a kurdish village in northern iraq
thousands died that led to the Chemical
Weapons Convention of 1993 which out
lost their use stockpiling production
and transfer yet North Korea Egypt
Angola and South Sudan have not signed
it Myanmar and Israel did sign but have
not ratified the treaty after
international pressure and threat of a
US military strike Syria will formally
join the convention in October but even
if disarmament becomes a reality the use
of chemical weapons could happen again
there or elsewhere a 1995 sarin gas
attack in a Tokyo subway was carried out
by a cult subject to no treaty in the
future it may be non-state actors that
pose the greatest threat
[Music]
